bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: Walt Whitman to Beatrice Gilchrist, 21 September [1877]
bibl.orgName: Walt Whitman Collection, 1842–1957, Rare Book & Manuscript Library, University of Pennsylvania
The Charles E. Feinberg Collection of the Papers of Walt Whitman, 1839–1919, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

body.p: Your letter came an hour ago, & we have all read it with deepest interest—praying that all will go well with your dearest mother—& having no doubt it will—Hattie has been quite unwell for two nights, & yesterday—a sort of Cholera morbus & fever—but is pretty well to-daytoday,—is dress'ddressed & down stairs again—the rest all well—
—I rec'dreceived a letter from Herby—he said he had written to you all, at the same time with mine—He had arrived at Esopus, & was having good times—

—As I was down by the market here three hours ago I met Mr Stafford, & have had a talk & a short ride with him—he came up with a load of cabbages, which he sold, & has just started for home—All are well, (although Mrs S is hardly so, either, I think overworked & too much tasked & nervous)

—I have rec'dreceived I think from Edw'dEdward Carpenter the Daily News (London) with a long very fine resumé-article on Thiers—which I will bring or send you, for yourself & (by & by) your mother's reading—
—I am feeling comfortable—go out some hours every day, enjoying the fine Sept:September weather—
